video.title: TEDTalks: Defying Disease
video.synopsis: Can we outsmart Mother Nature to cure some of the world's deadliest diseases? These TED speakers propose some astonishing solutions.

episodes.synopsis: William Li presents a new way of treating cancer: preventing the growth of blood vessels that feed a tumor.
episodes.title: William Li: Can We Eat to Starve Cancer?

episodes.synopsis: Alan Russell studies regenerative medicine and introduces a process that can signal the body to rebuild itself.
episodes.title: Alan Russell on Regenerating Our Bodies

episodes.synopsis: Cambridge researcher Aubrey de Grey argues that aging is merely a disease -- and a curable one at that.
episodes.title: Aubrey de Grey Says We Can Avoid Aging

episodes.synopsis: Cardiovascular disease kills more people than everything else combined. How will changing our eating habits save lives?
episodes.title: Dean Ornish on the World's Killer Diet

episodes.synopsis: A TED Prize winner calls for a new global system that can identify and contain pandemics before they spread.
episodes.title: Larry Brilliant Wants to Stop Pandemics

episodes.synopsis: Polio is almost eradicated. But as Bruce Aylward says: Almost isn't good enough with a disease this terrifying.
episodes.title: Bruce Aylward: How We'll Stop Polio for Good

episodes.synopsis: Biochemist Joe DeRisi talks about amazing new ways to diagnose viruses (and treat the illnesses they cause) using DNA.
episodes.title: Joe DeRisi Solves Medical Mysteries

episodes.synopsis: Nobel-winning chemist Kary Mullis, who watched a friend die when antibiotics failed, unveils a new cure.
episodes.title: Kary Mullis's Next-Gen Cure for Killer Infections

episodes.synopsis: What controls aging? Cynthia Kenyon has found a simple genetic mutation that can double the lifespan of a simple worm.
episodes.title: Cynthia Kenyon: Experiments That Hint of Longer Lives

episodes.synopsis: How are advances in vaccine design, production and distribution bringing us closer to eliminating a host of global threats?
episodes.title: Seth Berkley: HIV and Flu -- The Vaccine Strategy

episodes.synopsis: Too often, says David Agus cancer treatments have a short-sighted focus on individual cells. He suggests a new approach.
episodes.title: David Agus: A New Strategy in the War on Cancer

episodes.synopsis: Nicholas Christakis reveals how social networks can be used to detect epidemics earlier than ever.
episodes.title: Nicholas Christakis: How Social Networks Predict Epidemics

episodes.synopsis: Psychologist Kelly McGonigal urges us to see stress as positive and introduces an unsung mechanism for stress reduction: reaching out to others.
episodes.title: Kelly McGonigal: How to Make Stress Your Friend

episodes.synopsis: Surgeon Peter Attia examines the relationship between diabetes and obesity, and how assumptions may be leading us to wage the wrong medical war.
episodes.title: Peter Attia: Is the Obesity Crisis Hiding a Bigger Problem?

episodes.synopsis: Dermatologist Richard Weller's research shows that sunlight causes nitric oxide to be released into the body, benefiting the cardiovascular system.
episodes.title: Richard Weller: Could the Sun Be Good for Your Heart?

episodes.synopsis: Circadian neuroscientist Russell Foster busts some myths about sleep and hints at some bold new uses of sleep as a predictor of mental health.
episodes.title: Russell Foster: Why Do We Sleep?

episodes.synopsis: Why does malaria still kill so many every year? Sonia Shah's look at the history of malaria reveals three big-picture challenges to its eradication.
episodes.title: Sonia Shah: 3 Reasons We Still Haven't Gotten Rid of Malaria
